So today, it's my great
pleasure to be here

to share with you
some of my recent work

on using active compliance
for robust manipulation.
So let me explain what that is.

So I work on robotic
manipulation, which is basically

trying to make a
robot do useful tasks
with their arms and the hands.

As you may have
seen in recent news,

there has been a lot of very
impressive robotic manipulation
demos on YouTube.

Those companies make
beautiful hardware

and have very impressive
manipulation skills
demonstrated.

But when can we see
them not only in YouTube
but in our daily life?

And when can we have
robots actually around us

to do the chores that
we don't want to do?

So somehow there is
still a gap here.

And in my opinion,
the gap is mostly

about the robustness of
those manipulation skills.

Basically, you need
the ability to handle

all kinds of uncertainties
and disturbances

that are inevitable
in real life.

And in my talk today, I'm going
to talk about one particular way

to improve the robustness
of robotic manipulation.
This is active compliance.

So let me explain
what this word means.

So compliance is
a motor property

that describes the relationship
between force and motion.

So even for the same motion,
if you use different compliance

profile, it will react to
external force very differently.

So this is something humans
are very good at utilizing.

So, for example, this is me
trying to grab the empty plate.

I didn't pay attention to
some other place in my way.

So if I do the graphing
with low compliance, which

means my hand is very
rigid, I literally
push away any obstacles.

I can carry out the
original desired motion.

But if I execute my motion
with high compliance,

basically, my motion will
deform around the obstacle.

Here's another example where
I'm just swinging my arms,
but there's obstacle in the way.
This time, it's a rigid wall.

If I do it with low
compliance, I'm hurting myself.

I'm going to introduce
a lot of contact force.

If I do it with
high compliance, I

can actually engage the
contact pretty gently.

So as you can see,
those different profiles
are good for different things.

A low compliance, or in
other words, high stiffness,

is good for precise
tracking under disturbances.

But they can be
dangerous when you
are engaging unknown contacts.

The high compliance control
is good for adapting

to new constraints, but they are
very susceptible to disturbance
forces.

And the good thing is
that for our robot,

it is possible to
implement any of them.

So this is called
active compliance.

You can implement any
compliance profile
on a robot using control.

Then this brings us with the
question, for manipulation,

can we design our control to
take the best of both worlds?

So that's basically
the central question
I'm trying to answer today.

to you, how exactly

does compliance help
in manipulation?

So for the analytical
perspective,

the central question
here is, can we

improve the robustness
of manipulation?

Can we make

in the face of uncertainties

So we might as well

how exactly does
manipulation fail?

So let's zoom in
to the exact time

instant of the failure
of a manipulation task.

And actually, we can
summarize the failures
into two failure cases.
One is unexpected contact mode.

So a contact mode is
basically saying--

a contact point could
be either sticking
or sliding or disengaging.
They are discrete modes.

You might be expecting
some of them.

But for example, in this
case if the contact point

with the robot suddenly changed
from sticking to sliding,

that basically marks
the failure of the task.

So the second failure
case is we call it
kinematic ill-conditioning.

Let me explain
with this example.

Here this robot is attempting
to slide the white item upwards
and lift it up.

But due to some calibration
error, its velocity is wrong.

Its velocity has a component
that is penetrating the wall.

So instead, the robot is
creating huge internal forces

at the contact, which
eventually breaks the fingertip.

So these are the
two failure modes.
How can we avoid them?

I will start from
the second one,
the kinematic ill-conditioning.

It turns out this
situation happens when you
have a constraint violation.

For any manipulation
problem, there
are two sources of constraints.

One from the context in
the system and the other
is basically your control.

So if you apply high stiffness,
like very rigid control

on a robot, you're basically
applying a constraint
to the system.

And that constraint might not
be compatible with what already
exists in your environment.

So at any time instant,
those constraints

are linear constraints
on the system

velocity, which means we're
having infeasible linear system.

Then we can use our
knowledge of linear algebra

and use the condition
number of this linear system

to quantify how far
away the system is
towards being infeasible.

With some robotics-related
post-processing,
we can use it as a metric.
We call it the corruption index.

This basically
describes how badly
the system is ill conditioned.

So in this analysis,
we can see how
compliance can be helpful here.

Basically, compliance can
be helpful by giving up
some controls.

If there are already
constrained in the system,
then your robot will--

tell robot, please
just let it go.

You don't have to have full
control of every single degree
of freedom.

So this way of
selectively applying

control in a certain
direction can

be implemented by a certain
compliance control method called
hybrid force-velocity control.

This is a traditional
method, very

popular in industry-like
surface polishing.
The idea is very simple.

You look at your
robot's action space.

You can decompose
them into two parts.

In one of them, you can let
the robot be very stiff.

You do high stiffness control,
which is usually represented
by velocity control here.

In the other space, you
can do soft force control.

And apparently, there
are many options

of selecting the number
of dimensionality

and the direction of
those controls to be--

on the one hand, you still
want to finish your task.

You still want to achieve
the desired system velocity.

On the other hand, you want to
minimize the crashing index.

So you stay away from
getting your condition.

And that problem of
computing the best hybrid

force-velocity control can
be solved in closed form.

So we call it the
hybrid servoing problem.

And we show that
our algorithm can

find basically the optimal
solution for most problems
within one milliseconds.

And the result is very robust
execution of some quantization
manipulation task.

And you can do so
without precise modeling.

And then we can use

in sampling-based planner, like

style planning where start with
a tree in your state space.

You randomly sample a
state in this state space

and try to find the state
that is on the tree,

but closer to the
randomly sampled point.
This is a typical RRT.
We change the extension step.

So instead of growing
the newly selected node

towards the newly sampled node,
we grow multiple branches.

We grow one branch for
every feasible contact mode.

And then we compute
the stability margins

for the newly sampled branches
and only keep the ones
that are past some threshold.

So this way, we essentially
do sampling-based planning,

but we maintain a solution
with high robustness.

And this method is very
effective in planning
multi-contact manipulation.

So for motions with 5

So you can typically
describe compliance
by a spring mass damper system.
Basically, your force is--

like the force you feel is
generated by some inertia,
some spring, and some damper.

And to simplify things here, we

is not super fast.

So the acceleration and the

So we can ignore

look at the spring term,
which is parameterized

by a stiffness matrix,
that's your spring

constant, and a
reference position,

which is at which position
your spring will have no force.

So let's consider a simple
one-dimensional manipulation
problem.
You have a one-dimensional cart.
It has a position.
It has some spring constant.

And then you drive this
cart towards a wall.

And, of course,

It will record a force

The question is, can you recover

here from the data we have?

Unfortunately, you cannot,
because either of the two
situations could happen.

You could have a very rigid
spring which only deforms

a little bit, or you could
have a very soft spring
that deforms a lot.

We don't know where
the reference is.

That's why it's ill-conditioned
to compute the spring constant.

So our solution is
actually instead

precisely recover

what compliance
human was using, we

chose to find one compliance
profile that actually
is very useful.
It's useful enough.
And our strategy is very simple.

Our robot is only compliant in
the direction of large force
feedback.

So that means if you
look at your data set

and at any time instant, if
you see a large force, that

means you can set the robot to
be very soft in that direction.
Use a low stiffness.

In all other directions, you
make the robot very rigid.

So this is a very simple
rule, but it turns out

to be highly
effective in two ways.

First, it gives you robustness
towards force disturbance
in any direction.
So why is that?

So imagine you have
some disturbance

force in the direction

Since you have a
large feedback force,

that disturbance has
to be even larger

to cancel out your
current feedback force
to break the current contact.

If the disturbance force
is in other directions,

well, you have a high
stiffness control.

So you naturally is resistant

So that's where the
